newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian cotton ranged on low buying, few supplies.
newsitem.headline: Indian cotton ranged on low buying, few supplies.

text.p: Cotton prices were steady in a narrow price band on the local market on Tuesday, dealers said.
Fresh mill buying remained low but negligible supplies kept prices quiet.
"Supplies were affected due to ongoing nationwide strike by the transport operators to protes against service tax and hike in the insurance premium," one dealer said.

In spot deals Bengal-deshi was quiet at 890/930 rupees per maund (37.32 kg) while Punjab saw-ginned was steady at 1,525/1,660 rupees per maund. F-414 was available at the previous level of 1,880/1,900 rupees per maund.
Gujarat Kalyan (medium-staple) was steady at 13,200/13,500 rupees per candy (355.56 kg).
"Superior varieties too remained steady despite shortage of ready stock as mill buying remained at low ebb," a broker said.
Gujarat Sankar-4 (long-staple) was quiet at 16,500/17,000 rupees per candy for the average variety and at 18,000/19,500 rupees for the superior variety.

Sentiment was subdued at the close in the absence of any release of fresh export quota by the Indian government. Reports that the Indian government prefers the export of value-added cotton yarn instead of raw cotton also softened market sentiment. --Bombay Commodities +91-22-265 9000
